children.value: There are 9 built-in edges in G6:
line: straight line without control points;
polyline: polyline with one or more control points;
cubic-vertical：vertical cubic bezier curve. The user can not assign the control point for this type of edge;
cubic-horizontal: horizontal cubic bezier curve. The user can not assign the control point for this type of edge;
The table below shows the built-in edges and their special properties:
A straight line connected two end nodes:
- Refer to properties of line for more information
A polyline with one or more control points:
is the set of all the control points of polyline. If it is not assigned, G6 will calculate it by
- Refer to properties of polyline for more information
An arc connects two end nodes:
- control the bending and direction by
- Refer to properties of arc for more informatio
A quadratic bezier curve with one control point:
- The curve will be bended on the center if the
- Refer to properties of quadratic for more informatio
A cubic bezier curve with two control points:
- The curve will be bended on the position of 1/3 and 2/3 if the
- Refer to properties of cubic for more informatio
The vertical cubic bezier curve. The user can not assign the control point for this type of edge
The horizontal cubic bezier curve. The user can not assign the control point for this type of edge
Self-loop edge. Refer to properties of loop for more informatio
The id of the target node
The type of the edge. It can be the type of a Built-in Edge, or a custom Edge.
The index of link points on the source node. The link point is the intersection of the edge and related node
The index of link points on the target node. The link point is the intersection of the edge and related node
The label text of the edge
is an object to configure the stroke color, shadow, and so on. Here is the commonly used properties in
The width of the response area for interaction. In other words, when the edge is too thin to be hitted by mouse, enlarge the value of
The arrow on the end of the edge. When
, show a default arrow on the end of the edge. User can customize an arrow by path, e.g.:
path: 'M 0,0 L 20,10 L 20,-10 Z', // Customize the path for the arrow
The arrow on the start of the edge. When
, show a default arrow on the start of the edge. User can customize an arrow by path, e.g.:
path: 'M 0,0 L 20,10 L 20,-10 Z', // Customize the path for the arrow
The blur degree of the shadow
The x offset of the shadow
The y offset of the shadow

The style of the dash line. It is an array that describes the length of gaps and line segments. If the number of the elements in the array is odd, the elements will be dulplicated. Such as [5, 15, 25] will be regarded as [5, 15, 25, 5, 15, 25]
The type of the mouse when hovering the edge. The options are the same as
is a string which indicates the content of the label.

The following code shows how to configure
There are three methods to configure edges: Configure edges globally when instantiating a Graph; Configure edges in their data; Configure edges by
That means, if there are same configurations in different ways, the way with higher priority will take effect.

properties.ariaLabel: configure globally when instantiating graph permalink

children.value: to configure all the nodes globally:
// Other properties for all the nodes
To configure different nodes with different properties, you can write the properties into their data individually:
By this way, we can configure different nodes with different properties.
. It does not take effect otherwise;
It has the highest priority that will rewrite the same properties configured by other ways;
Each edge will be updated when adding or updating items. It will cost a lot when the amount of the data is large.
By writing the properties into the data, we adjust the style and the label of the edges of '9-10' and '11-12'.
// Move the label of this edge
// refY is the offset along the clockwise down direction
// Set the color, line dash, line width, and style of the label of this edge
// Whether to rotate the label according to the edge
// The line width of the stroke
